unicode.value: This is a VLO for learning text comprehension through horror stories
TEXT COMPREHENSION AND PRODUCTION THROUGH HORROR STORIES
4. What is text comprehension and production?

In the following video game, you will find the necessary vocabulary for the written part that you must complete. Remember to write down the vocabulary. You can pause the game whenever you need to. Also, do not forget that it is a maze, and you must escape from the ghosts that chase you. To move your character, you must use the arrow keys on the keyboard.
Provide instruction on how the cloze activity should be completed. Default text will be entered if there are no changes to this field.
Lea el párrafo que aparece abajo y complete las palabras que faltan.
If this option is checked, submitted answers with different capitalization will be marked as incorrect.

Word List:

eerie
taxes
blinding
rob
trembling
slip of paper
elegant
dreadful
afford
edges
dimmed
stepped through

Level One: Eternal Nightmare


In 1995, when video games were becoming an essential part of children’s lives, there was a poor boy named Hiro.
He couldn’t 1. afford a video game console. Every cold night, he walked through the streets of New York selling candies to help his parents pay 2. taxes and buy food.
Sometimes, he would stop in front of store windows, watching other children receive consoles and games for Christmas, while nobody paid attention to him.

One night, while Hiro was selling candies as usual, an 3. elegant tall man wearing a black suit, dark glasses, and an expensive watch noticed him.
The man saw that Hiro was alone. He walked closer and offered him the chance to participate in a test for a new horror video game.

At first, Hiro thought the man wanted to 4. rob him and tried to avoid him. But the man insisted, promising that if Hiro participated, he would receive a console loaded with video games. Still, Hiro hesitated.

Then the man began asking Hiro questions, staring straight into his eyes. Feeling intimidated, Hiro answered honestly.
When asked about his family, he replied that they were poor and often hungry.

Finally, Hiro accepted. The man handed him a 5. slip of paper with an address and said,

“Be at this house tomorrow at 6:00 a.m. You’ll start working with us.”

The Test


The next day, Hiro arrived at the address. The building looked like an abandoned hospital.
He thought he was in the wrong place until he heard the man’s voice calling him.
Startled, Hiro turned and saw the man opening the door, inviting him inside.
As he 6. stepped through , the flickering lights 7. dimmed and some went out.

The place was 8. dreadful . The smell of dust and rust filled the air.
He was led to a small, windowless room where a woman was waiting.
She took out a strange helmet—supposedly the console of the future—and handed it to him.

The game began. Shadows flickered at the 9. edges of his vision.
The hospital around him had transformed—blood covered the floors, and 10. eerie voices whispered commands into his mind.


Inside the Nightmare


In the first level, Hiro was told to enter the next room.
There, he found tools to unlock other rooms.
He picked up a knife and ran through the hallway, only to meet a monstrous creature with dozens of eyes.
Terrified, Hiro began to cry. The room went completely dark, and distorted voices echoed inside his head:

“Your family will never be safe. You will be trapped here forever.”
Meanwhile, in the real world, the man and the woman watched Hiro’s reactions from behind a glass window.
They saw his tears and 11. trembling hands. His pulse was speeding up dangerously, and they feared he might have a heart attack.

But they didn’t care. That was the objective — to test the console, no matter the cost.
They laughed coldly, already thinking about their next test subject.


Breaking Free


Inside the game, Hiro’s mind filled with terror and despair.
But then, memories of his family appeared—his mother’s voice, his father’s smile, their small but warm home.

A 12. blinding light engulfed the virtual hospital.
The shadows screamed as Hiro took control of the machine.
Suddenly, he broke free from the game and returned to the real world… but not as a boy.

He had become a gigantic beast, his body covered in black scales and his eyes burning with fury.

The man and the woman tried to run away, but the monstrous Hiro stood in the doorway.
A deafening roar echoed through the building. Moments later, only screams filled the air.

When the police investigated days later, they found no trace of the man, the woman, or Hiro.
Only the helmet remained—its screen still flickering with the words:

LEVEL ONE: ETERNAL NIGHTMARE.
PRESS START TO CONTINUE.
If this option is set, each word will be marked as the learner types it rather than all the words being marked the end of the exercise.

Enter the text for the cloze activity in to the cloze field by either pasting text from another source or by typing text directly into the field.

To select words to hide, double click on the word to select it and click on the Hide/Show Word button below.

More than one possible answer can be defined enclosing them with pipes (|). I.e.: |dog|cat|bird|

If left unchecked a small number of spelling and capitalization errors will be accepted. If checked only an exact match in spelling and capitalization will be accepted.

For example: If the correct answer is Elephant then both elephant and Eliphant will be judged "close enough" by the algorithm as it only has one letter wrong, even if "Check Capitalization" is on.

If capitalization checking is off in the above example, the lowercase e will not be considered a mistake and eliphant will also be accepted.

If both "Strict Marking" and "Check Capitalization" are set, the only correct answer is "Elephant". If only "Strict Marking" is checked and "Check Capitalization" is not, "elephant" will also be accepted.

Word List:

eerie
taxes
blinding
rob
trembling
slip of paper
elegant
dreadful
afford
edges
dimmed
stepped through

A 12. blinding light engulfed the virtual hospital.
The shadows screamed as Hiro took control of the machine.
Suddenly, he broke free from the game and returned to the real world… but not as a boy.

LEVEL ONE: ETERNAL NIGHTMARE.
PRESS START TO CONTINUE.

Cloze exercises are texts or sentences where students must fill in missing words. They are often used for the following purposes:

  1. To check knowledge of core course concepts (this could be a pre-check, formative exercise, or summative check).
  2. To check reading comprehension.
  3. To check vocabulary knowledge.
  4. To check word formation and/or grammatical competence.

If your goal is to test understanding of core concepts or reading comprehension

Write a summary of the concept or reading long enough to adequately test the target's knowledge, but short enough not to induce fatigue. Less than one typed page is probably adequate, but probably considerably less for young students or beginners.

Select words in the text thatare key to understanding the concepts. Thesewill probably be verbs, nouns, and key adverbs.Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test vocabulary knowledge

Write a text using the target vocabulary. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Highlight the target words in the text. Choose alternatives with one clear answer.

If your goal is to test word formation/grammar:

Write a text using the target forms. This text should be coherent and cohesive, and be of an appropriate length. Remember that the goal is not vocabulary knowledge, so the core meanings of the stem words should be well known to the students.

Highlight the target words in the text. Provide alternatives with the same word stem, but different affixes. It is a good idea to get a colleague to test the test/exercise to make sure there are no surprises!
Enter any feedback you wish to provide the learner with-in the feedback field. This field can be left blank.

afford (verb)
➤ To have enough money or resources to buy or do something.
Example: He couldn’t afford a video game console.
Meaning: He didn’t have enough money to buy it.

taxes (noun – plural)
➤ Money that people must pay to the government so it can provide services like schools, roads, and hospitals.
Example: Hiro sold candies to help his parents pay taxes.
Meaning: Payments made to the government.

elegant (adjective)
➤ Very beautiful, stylish, or graceful; showing good taste.
Example: The elegant man wore a black suit and dark glasses.
Meaning: He looked sophisticated and well-dressed.

rob (verb)
➤ To take something from a person or place by force or threat.
Example: Hiro thought the man wanted to rob him.
Meaning: To steal from someone.

slip of paper (noun phrase)
➤ A small, thin piece of paper used for writing short notes or messages.
Example: The man gave Hiro a slip of paper with an address.
Meaning: A little note or piece of paper.

stepped through (phrasal verb)
➤ To walk through an opening, such as a door or a passage.
Example: Hiro stepped through the door into the building.
Meaning: He entered or went inside through the doorway.

dimmed (verb – past tense of “dim”)
➤ To become less bright or less strong, especially referring to light.
Example: The lights dimmed and some went out.
Meaning: The lights became darker or weaker.

dreadful (adjective)
➤ Very bad, terrible, or frightening.
Example: The place was dreadful.
Meaning: It was horrible and scary.

edges (noun – plural)
➤ The outer parts or borders of something.
Example: Shadows flickered at the edges of his vision.
Meaning: The sides or limits of what he could see.

eerie (adjective)
➤ Strange and scary in a mysterious or unnatural way.
Example: Eerie voices whispered in his mind.
Meaning: The voices were weird and frightening.

trembling (verb – present participle of “tremble”)
➤ Shaking slightly because of fear, cold, or weakness.
Example: They saw his tears and trembling hands.
Meaning: His hands were shaking because he was scared.

blinding (adjective)
➤ So bright or strong that it makes it hard to see.
Example: A blinding light engulfed the virtual hospital.
Meaning: The light was so bright it covered everything.

Cambridge University Press. (2019). How can I improve my reading? A brief guide with tips for improving reading in English. Cambridge Assessment English. https://www.cambridgeenglish.org/images/562912-tips-for-reading-students.pdf

Gladic Miralles, J., & Cautín-Epifani, V. (2016). Una mirada a los modelos multimodales de comprensión y aprendizaje a partir del texto. Literatura y Lingüística, 33(33), 357–380. Pontificia Universidad Católica de Chile. https://doi.org/10.4067/S0716-58112016000200017

Van Hout-Wolters, B., & Schnotz, W. (Eds.). (1992). Text comprehension and learning from text. Taylor & Francis. https://www.researchgate.net/publication/343020042_Text_comprehension_and_learning_from_text_An_introduction
This is a VLO for learning text comprehension through horror stories
